segment.source: 4752(S) A member was removed from a security-disabled global group.
segment.target: 4752(S) A member was removed from a security-disabled global group.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4752(S) A member was removed from a security-disabled global group.
segment.target: Describes security event 4752(S) A member was removed from a security-disabled global group.

segment.source: 4752(S): A member was removed from a security-disabled global group.
segment.target: 4752(S): A member was removed from a security-disabled global group.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time member was removed from the security-disabled (distribution) global group.
segment.target: This event generates every time member was removed from the security-disabled (distribution) global group.

segment.source: This event generates only on domain controllers.
segment.target: This event generates only on domain controllers.

segment.source: For every removed member you will get separate 4752 event.
segment.target: For every removed member you will get separate 4752 event.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “remove member from the group” operation.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “remove member from the group” operation.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “remove member from the group” operation.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “remove member from the group” operation.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Member:
segment.target: Member:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that was removed from the group.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that was removed from the group.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the group name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the group name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: distinguished name of account that was removed from the group.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: distinguished name of account that was removed from the group.

segment.source: For example: “CN=Auditor,CN=Users,DC=contoso,DC=local”.
segment.target: For example: “CN=Auditor,CN=Users,DC=contoso,DC=local”.

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “-”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “-”.

segment.source: Note The LDAP API references an LDAP object by its distinguished name (DN).
segment.target: Note The LDAP API references an LDAP object by its distinguished name (DN).

segment.source: A DN is a sequence of relative distinguished names (RDN) connected by commas.
segment.target: A DN is a sequence of relative distinguished names (RDN) connected by commas.

segment.source: An RDN is an attribute with an associated value in the form attribute=value; .
segment.target: An RDN is an attribute with an associated value in the form attribute=value; .

segment.source: These are examples of RDNs attributes:
segment.target: These are examples of RDNs attributes:

segment.source: • DC - domainComponent
segment.target: • DC - domainComponent

segment.source: • CN - commonName
segment.target: • CN - commonName

segment.source: • OU - organizationalUnitName
segment.target: • OU - organizationalUnitName

segment.source: • O - organizationName
segment.target: • O - organizationName

segment.source: Group:
segment.target: Group:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of the group from which the member was removed.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of the group from which the member was removed.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the group name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the group name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Group Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the group from which the member was removed.
segment.target: Group Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the group from which the member was removed.

segment.source: For example: ServiceDesk
segment.target: For example: ServiceDesk

segment.source: Group Domain Type = UnicodeString: domain name of the group from which the member was removed.
segment.target: Group Domain Type = UnicodeString: domain name of the group from which the member was removed.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: Built-in groups: Builtin
segment.target: Built-in groups: Builtin

segment.source: Additional Information:
segment.target: Additional Information:

segment.source: Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of user privileges which were used during the operation, for example, SeBackupPrivilege.
segment.target: Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of user privileges which were used during the operation, for example, SeBackupPrivilege.

segment.source: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “-”.
segment.target: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “-”.

segment.source: See full list of user privileges in “Table 8.
segment.target: See full list of user privileges in “Table 8.

segment.source: User Privileges.”.
segment.target: User Privileges.”.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4752(S): A member was removed from a security-disabled global group.
segment.target: For 4752(S): A member was removed from a security-disabled global group.

segment.source: Type of monitoring required
segment.target: Type of monitoring required

segment.source: Recommendation
segment.target: Recommendation

segment.source: Removal of members from distribution groups: You might need to monitor the removal of members from distribution groups.
segment.target: Removal of members from distribution groups: You might need to monitor the removal of members from distribution groups.

segment.source: If you need to monitor each time a member is removed from a distribution group, to see who removed the member and when, monitor this event.
segment.target: If you need to monitor each time a member is removed from a distribution group, to see who removed the member and when, monitor this event.

segment.source: Typically, this event is used as an informational event, to be reviewed if needed.
segment.target: Typically, this event is used as an informational event, to be reviewed if needed.

segment.source: High-value distribution groups: You might have a list of critical distribution groups in the organization, and need to specifically monitor these groups for the removal of members (or for other changes).
segment.target: High-value distribution groups: You might have a list of critical distribution groups in the organization, and need to specifically monitor these groups for the removal of members (or for other changes).

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “GroupGroup Name” values that correspond to the high-value distribution groups.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “GroupGroup Name” values that correspond to the high-value distribution groups.

segment.source: Distribution groups with required members: You might need to ensure that for certain distribution groups, particular members are never removed.
segment.target: Distribution groups with required members: You might need to ensure that for certain distribution groups, particular members are never removed.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “GroupGroup Name” that corresponds to the group of interest, and the “MemberSecurity ID” of the members who should not be removed.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “GroupGroup Name” that corresponds to the group of interest, and the “MemberSecurity ID” of the members who should not be removed.

segment.source: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.
segment.target: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.

segment.source: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.
segment.target: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “MemberSecurity ID” that correspond to the high-value account or accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “MemberSecurity ID” that correspond to the high-value account or accounts.

segment.source: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.
segment.target: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.

segment.source: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.
segment.target: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.

segment.source: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “SubjectSecurity ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.
segment.target: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “SubjectSecurity ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.

segment.source: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “MemberSecurity ID” that correspond to the accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “SubjectSecurity ID” and “MemberSecurity ID” that correspond to the accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.
segment.target: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.

segment.source: Accounts of different types: You might want to ensure that certain actions are performed only by certain account types, for example, local or domain account, machine or user account, vendor or employee account, and so on.
segment.target: Accounts of different types: You might want to ensure that certain actions are performed only by certain account types, for example, local or domain account, machine or user account, vendor or employee account, and so on.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to an action you want to monitor for certain account types, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” to see whether the account type is as expected.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to an action you want to monitor for certain account types, review the “SubjectSecurity ID” to see whether the account type is as expected.

segment.source: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).
segment.target: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).

segment.source: Monitor this event for the “SubjectAccount Domain” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event for the “SubjectAccount Domain” corresponding to accounts from another domain or “external” accounts.

segment.source: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should not typically perform any actions.
segment.target: Restricted-use computers or devices: You might have certain computers, machines, or devices on which certain people (accounts) should not typically perform any actions.

segment.source: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “SubjectSecurity ID” that you are concerned about.
segment.target: Monitor the target Computer: (or other target device) for actions performed by the “SubjectSecurity ID” that you are concerned about.

segment.source: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.
segment.target: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.

segment.source: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
segment.target: Monitor “SubjectAccount Name” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
